ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
skills: reaching and analyzing science articles, reading and analyzing data
 
knowledge: how green energy systems compare and contrast to one another, the pros and cons of each type of energy system, ways that green energy systems can be incorporated (carbon taxes paying for green energy systems research, for example)
This course was essentially a survey of types of green energy so I learned about the way each of these systems works alongside their benefits and drawbacks.
Learned about Green Energy Systems and the requirements for a clean and safe sustainable future.
A lot. Mainly about the connection between different subject fields, biology, physics, geology..
working knowledge of green energy, familiarity with peer reviewed scientific papers
General introduction to renewable energy types

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strength: explains and presents information in a way that is easily accessible for people who don't major in STEM (i.e. mentioning the political and economic pros and cons so that students from all majors found something interesting and stimulating in the course)

weaknesses: the style of the course just being in lecture. I would have liked if maybe we had 45 minutes of lecture and then 45 of discussion and questions.

Strengths: I found the descriptions of the systems to be sufficient despite the fact that Professor Khalil omitted most of the specific equations that governed them. I also liked that the main assignments for the course were team-based.

Weaknesses: Although I liked the team component of the assignments, they frankly felt a little bit bland. The three homework assignments were somewhat interesting, but the midterm and final assignments were just reading and summarizing papers which got pretty old after a while. I suppose I felt like I learned the reviewed topics in depth though.
Strengths are the straightforwards and direct assignments.
Should have more interaction between teacher and students
this course is accessible for non stem majors and works well in a remote setup. I think some of the assignments could have been more thoughtfully constructed to promote learning.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Especially as a non-STEM major interested in pursuing either an energy studies or climate change and its solutions certificate, I found the information really relevant, understandable, and applicable to the world as we know it. I would definitely recommend this as a summer course that can feed your intellectual curiosity without overwhelming you too much.
I would recommend this course if you're looking for a survey of types of green energy without taxing yourself with too high of a workload.
Yes especially for those not in science majors.
Yes, because it can help students to learn more knowledge
I would recommend this course to non STEM majors looking for an extra credit or to knock out the science requirement
Yes

narratives.question_text: How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments: I am looking to pursue a climate change and its solutions or an energy studies certificate! I am also applying for part time internships during the year to work with New York's environmental coalitions advocating for tighter accountability for carbon pricing. So, all of the information I learned and all of the notes I took will continue to help me in my educational and professional endeavors. I am really grateful for the ability to have learned from one of the top professors in this field, and am looking forward to meeting him in person.
I feel that this course has helped me understand how to read and digest research papers which could help me learn more complex or niche subjects in the future.
Look forward to the future of a sustainable planet.
In many fields, expecially in the vision of overall situation
I will use the knowledge imparted by this course as a citizen, voter, and journalist focused on agricultural and food system issues.
